title: Synthetic Recap
body:
INDIANAPOLIS — On a night where the basket seemed as wide as the ocean for one man, the Indiana Pacers rode a historic, singular performance to a grinding 92-82 victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

The story was not the final score, but the staggering 47-point eruption from Pacers guard Reggie Miller. In an era defined by physical, low-scoring contests, Miller’s output was nothing short of an offensive supernova, single-handedly outscoring the entire Hawks starting lineup for long stretches of the evening.

Miller was uncontainable, a flurry of motion and pinpoint shooting. He attacked from every angle, burying long-range jumpers, slicing to the rim, and capitalizing with ruthless efficiency at the foul line. His 47 points, a monument carved from the stone of Atlanta’s defense, were more than half of his team’s total output. The rest of the Pacers’ starting five combined for a mere 25 points, content to feed the hot hand and watch a master at work.

While Miller provided the firepower, the Pacers’ defense provided the backbone. They held the Hawks to a paltry 82 points, with Dikembe Mutombo’s 13 points and 15 rebounds a lone bright spot in an otherwise anemic offensive display for the visitors.

In the end, this was Reggie Miller’s night, a breathtaking display of scoring prowess that overwhelmed an entire opponent. The final buzzer sounded not just on a Pacers win, but on a performance for the ages, a reminder that on any given night, one man can become the entire game.
